summary_of_threads_started_this_week:
Peter Todd emphasizes the economic consequences of the Replace-by-Fee (RBF) Rule 6 within Bitcoin's miner transaction selection, highlighting a potential vulnerability to free-relay attacks due to prioritizing transactions with higher fee rates over those with higher absolute fees but lower rates. Todd proposes implementing a Replace-by-Fee-Rate (RBFR) mechanism to counteract these attacks and promote more economically rational mining practices, despite potential disruptions to wallet applications that adjust fees in small increments.

Or Sattath, alongside Bolton Bailey et al., delves into the implications of quantum computing on blockchain security, presenting a scenario where a quantum miner could exploit Grover's algorithm to facilitate a 51% attack with less computational power. This research underscores the urgent need for blockchain protocols to evolve in preparation for future quantum threats, despite the current technological limitations making such attacks infeasible.

Martin Habovštiak introduces a proposal dubbed "anyone can boost," aiming to enhance Bitcoin transaction efficiency by allowing transactions to be boosted through a novel method that bypasses existing issues with anchor outputs and CPFP methods. This approach requires a soft fork for implementation and poses considerations regarding network integrity and fee betting practices. Meanwhile, discussions initiated by Antoine Poinsot and Ben Carman on the Great Consensus Cleanup and modifying Bitcoin's leaf versioning approach, respectively, stimulate community engagement on refining network efficiency, security, and feature management. For detailed insights, resources include the [Original Full-RBF opt-in pull request](https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/6871), [One-shot replace-by-fee-rate - the status quo](https://petertodd.org/2024/one-shot-replace-by-fee-ratethe-status-quo), [Replace-by-fee-rate success rate](https://petertodd.org/2024/replace-by-fee-rate-success-rate), [arXiv paper on quantum computing and blockchain](https://arxiv.org/abs/2403.08023), and discussions on [DelvingBitcoin.org](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/great-consensus-cleanup-revival/710) and [DelvingBitcoin.org on 64-bit arithmetic soft fork](https://delvingbitcoin.org/t/64-bit-arithmetic-soft-fork/397?u=benthecarman).

new_threads_this_week.title: A Free-Relay Attack Exploiting RBF Rule #6
new_threads_this_week.summary:
- RBF Rule 6 affects Bitcoin transaction priorities and introduces vulnerability to free-relay attacks.
- Replace-by-Fee-Rate (RBFR) mitigates these attacks by requiring significant fee-rate increases for replacements.
- Public discussions confirm no objections to revealing vulnerabilities, highlighting financial barriers to attack execution.

new_threads_this_week.summary:

- Quantum miners could orchestrate effective attacks using Grover's algorithm, requiring significantly less effort for mining.
- The study highlights the urgent need for blockchain protocol adaptations to counter future quantum threats.
